solution:
# Function 1: Add element safely
def add_element(items, element):
    """Add element to set.
    
    Args:
        items (set): Set to modify
        element (any): Element to add
    
    Returns:
        set: Modified set
    """
    items.add(element)
    return items

# Function 2: Remove element safely (no error)
def safe_remove(items, element):
    """Remove element without error if missing.
    
    Args:
        items (set): Set to modify
        element (any): Element to remove
    
    Returns:
        set: Modified set
    """
    items.discard(element)
    return items

# Function 3: Add multiple elements
def add_multiple(items, new_items):
    """Add multiple elements to set.
    
    Args:
        items (set): Set to modify
        new_items (list): Elements to add
    
    Returns:
        set: Modified set
    """
    items.update(new_items)
    return items

# Function 4: Get and remove any element
def pop_any(items):
    """Remove and return any element, or None if empty.
    
    Args:
        items (set): Set to pop from
    
    Returns:
        any: Popped element or None
    """
    if items:
        return items.pop()
    return None

# Function 5: Keep only common elements (in-place)
def keep_common(set_a, set_b):
    """Keep only elements common to both sets (modify set_a).
    
    Args:
        set_a (set): Set to modify
        set_b (set): Reference set
    
    Returns:
        set: Modified set_a
    """
    set_a.intersection_update(set_b)
    return set_a

# Function 6: Create shallow copy
def copy_set(items):
    """Create copy of set.
    
    Args:
        items (set): Set to copy
    
    Returns:
        set: New set with same elements
    """
    return items.copy()
hints: Use .discard(element) for safe removal - no error if missing
Use .update(iterable) to add multiple elements at once
Check if set empty before .pop(), return None if empty
Use .intersection_update(set_b) or &= operator to keep only common
Use .copy() method or set(items) to create copy
